M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 215, § 6)

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 and the inherent equitable powers of the Probate and Family Court to modify existing orders to preserve the welfare of minor children.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and the Appeals Court have consistently held that the guiding principle in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that under the removal statute the words "upon cause shown" mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and then describes the custody/removal determination as driven by that standard. The court repeatedly characterizes the central question as how the children’s "best interests" are to be determined and analyzes custody and removal under that guiding principle. This aligns with the proposition that the SJC treats best interests of the child as the guiding principle in modification of custody/parenting‑time type decisions.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt:
The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ... the words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these “best interests” are to be determined.

Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. ... The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change...

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and the Appeals Court have consistently held that the guiding principle in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in removal and custody-related matters under G.L. c. 208, § 30, ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the child’s best interests, and it repeatedly frames the judge’s and the court’s analysis in terms of the ‘best interests of the children.’ It also describes joint custody as involving ‘a common desire to promote the children’s best interests.’ While the case focuses on removal in a joint-custody context rather than generic ‘modification of custody or parenting time,’ it clearly affirms that the guiding standard in these modification/removal disputes is the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… a minor child… shall not… be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders… ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … [T]he judge… determined that removal… was not in the best interests of the children.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and the Appeals Court have consistently held that the guiding principle in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the governing or controlling principle in custody determinations is the welfare (best interests) of the child and affirms the Probate Court’s decree on that basis. It quotes and endorses prior SJC precedent (Hersey, Jenkins) stating that the child’s welfare is the “dominating rule” and “controlling consideration,” and applies that standard in reviewing the custody/visitation decision. This aligns directly with the proposition that Massachusetts appellate courts treat the child’s best interests as the guiding principle in custody and parenting time matters, including modifications.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins… and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Rogers v. Rogers, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 337.raw_text: Rogers v. Rogers, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (1984)
Rogers v. Rogers, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 337.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that substantial physical and developmental changes, including a parent’s improved living conditions and the child’s maturation, justify revisiting previously issued custody orders.
Rogers v. Rogers, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 337.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Rogers v. Rogers and does not concern child custody, parental living conditions, or a child’s maturation. It addresses sovereign immunity and statutory interpretation relating to the Metropolitan District Commission and the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act. Because the case neither discusses nor establishes standards for modifying custody orders based on changed circumstances, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Rogers v. Rogers, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 337.relevant_excerpt: "In her complaint, the plaintiff alleges that she fell and was hurt because of a defect in a sidewalk maintained by the Metropolitan District Commission (MDC) along Revere Beach Parkway... [T]he judge denied the motion. The case went to trial before a jury, which brought in a verdict for the plaintiff..."

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that substantial physical and developmental changes, including a parent’s improved living conditions and the child’s maturation, justify revisiting previously issued custody orders.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion only briefly addresses custody procedure and does not discuss what kinds of factual changes (such as improved living conditions or a child’s maturation) justify revisiting custody. The court merely holds that any change in custody must be sought via a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, rather than by motion, and says nothing about substantial physical or developmental changes as grounds for modification. Thus it does not support the proposition claimed.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that substantial physical and developmental changes, including a parent’s improved living conditions and the child’s maturation, justify revisiting previously issued custody orders.
Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns service and review procedures for G.L. c. 209A abuse prevention orders and the mootness of the specific restraining orders at issue. It does not address child custody, parental fitness, or modification of custody orders based on changed circumstances such as improved living conditions or a child’s maturation. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition regarding revisiting custody orders due to substantial physical and developmental changes.
Zullo v. Goguen, 423 Mass. 679 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We turn to our second concern, which relates to the proper procedure for seeking review of a G. L. c. 209A order. Our prior cases have recognized G. L. c. 211, § 3, as the only available route to obtain such review… However, following our reasoning in Department of Revenue v. Jarvenpaa, 404 Mass. 177 (1989), we conclude that, henceforth, review of orders pursuant to G. L. c. 209A should not be initiated by petition under G. L. c. 211, § 3, but rather by the filing of an appeal in the Appeals Court.

Custody of Gabriel, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 12.raw_text: Custody of Gabriel, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 121 (2012)
Custody of Gabriel, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 12.proposition: The Court has authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 and the inherent equitable powers of the Probate and Family Court to modify existing orders to preserve the welfare of minor children.
Custody of Gabriel, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 12.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal case from the Massachusetts Appeals Court involving assault with intent to murder and prosecutorial misconduct, not a Probate and Family Court matter. It does not discuss M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, the jurisdiction or equitable powers of the Probate and Family Court, or the modification of orders concerning the welfare of minor children. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition.
Custody of Gabriel, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 12.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt. The opinion concerns criminal charges of assault with intent to murder and related trial issues, and does not address M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, Probate and Family Court jurisdiction, or modification of orders regarding minor children.]

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court has authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 and the inherent equitable powers of the Probate and Family Court to modify existing orders to preserve the welfare of minor children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for initial and modified custody under G.L. c. 209C and the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, but it does not mention G.L. c. 215, § 6, nor does it frame the Probate and Family Court’s authority as arising from that statute or from inherent equitable powers. The modification standard under c. 209C, § 20 is referenced only in passing and the court expressly declines to apply or analyze it here. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about the court’s power under c. 215, § 6 to modify existing orders to preserve the welfare of minor children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: "We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a)."

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Court has authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 and the inherent equitable powers of the Probate and Family Court to modify existing orders to preserve the welfare of minor children.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion is a Juvenile Court care-and-protection/adoption case decided under G.L. c. 119 and c. 210, not a Probate and Family Court matter, and it does not cite or discuss G.L. c. 215, § 6 or the Probate and Family Court’s inherent equitable powers. Its discussion focuses on standards for dispensing with consent, weighing competing adoption plans, expert testimony, and the scope of judicial review. There is no holding or reasoning about the court’s authority to modify existing orders under c. 215, § 6 to protect minor children, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” Adoption of a Minor (No. 2), 367 Mass. 684, 688 (1975).

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: In evaluating a change in circumstances, the Court should consider, inter alia, each parent’s current home environment and the developmental needs of the child.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly applies the Yannas/Hale removal framework, which requires examining the child’s quality of life, the custodial parent’s situation, and the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs. In doing so, the court discusses and compares the conditions in each parent’s home (stability, location, work schedules, extended family, etc.) and criticizes the trial judge for failing to weigh how each home environment and the child’s developmental needs would be affected by moving or not moving. This aligns with the proposition that, in assessing changed circumstances, the court should consider each parent’s current home environment and the child’s developmental needs.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge’s findings reflect some consideration of ‘the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, supra at 711. Hale v. Hale, supra at 817-820. Caleb was found to be a ‘physically and emotionally healthy’ boy whose ‘frequent, continuing and equal interaction . . . with each parent is most beneficial to him.’ … A second factor that appears important to the judge’s conclusion … is his close relationship with his grandparents and other members of his extended family living in or near Northborough.”

Ireland v. Ireland, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 49.raw_text: Ireland v. Ireland, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 495 (1997)
Ireland v. Ireland, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 49.proposition: In evaluating a change in circumstances, the Court should consider, inter alia, each parent’s current home environment and the developmental needs of the child.
Ireland v. Ireland, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 49.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns adult guardianship under the Massachusetts Uniform Durable Power of Attorney Act and General Laws c. 201; it does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or modifications based on a change in circumstances. Nowhere does the court discuss evaluating each parent’s home environment or the developmental needs of a child. The case instead focuses on honoring a principal’s nominated guardian absent good cause or disqualification, and on procedural rights in guardianship proceedings, so it does not support the claimed child-related proposition.
Ireland v. Ireland, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 49.relevant_excerpt: "We hold that when a principal has nominated his guardian by power of attorney pursuant to G. L. c. 201B, and protective proceedings are thereafter commenced, the Probate Court must, on proper petition, appoint the individual(s) nominated in the power, except for good cause or disqualification. G. L. c. 201B, § 3(b)."
